docs.title: Gmail Agent
docs.text: Welcome to the Gmail Agent documentation. Gmail Agent is an AI-powered email and calendar assistant that helps you manage your Gmail inbox and Google Calendar.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Gmail Agent uses LangChain and HuggingFace LLMs to intelligently process your emails, generate reply drafts, and manage calendar events with human oversight at every step.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Smart Email Classification - Automatically categorizes emails as needing reply, FYI only, meeting requests, or action items
  • AI-Powered Draft Replies - Generates contextual reply drafts with customizable tone
  • Meeting Scheduling - Extracts meeting details from emails and finds available calendar slots
  • Human-in-the-Loop Approval - Flags sensitive emails and low-confidence classifications for manual review
  • Trusted Sender Management - Build a list of known senders to streamline approval workflows

docs.title: Security First
docs.text:
Gmail Agent is designed with security in mind:

  • All email actions require explicit user approval
  • Sensitive content is flagged automatically
  • OAuth tokens are stored locally and never shared
  • Unknown senders trigger additional review

docs.title: Gmail Agent — AI-Powered Email & Calendar Assistant
Situation
docs.text: Managing a busy inbox involves repetitive tasks — classifying emails, drafting replies, and scheduling meetings — that consume significant time but follow predictable patterns. Modern LLMs have made it possible to automate these workflows intelligently, but most solutions operate as black boxes without meaningful human oversight.

docs.title: Task
docs.text: I built a full-stack AI assistant that automates email classification, reply drafting, and meeting scheduling while keeping the user firmly in control. The project served as a deep dive into LLM application development, integrating LangChain orchestration, Google APIs, and a human-in-the-loop approval system into a cohesive product.

docs.title: Action
docs.text:
Built a Streamlit web app with a modular architecture:

  • AI Agents (LangChain + HuggingFace Llama 3.1): An email classifier that categorises messages (needs reply, FYI, meeting request, action item) with confidence scoring; a reply drafter with tone control and iterative improvement; and a meeting scheduler that extracts details and proposes free calendar slots.
  • Human-in-the-Loop Approval: Every action (sending emails, creating calendar events) requires explicit user approval. A risk assessment layer automatically flags unknown senders, sensitive content, and low-confidence classifications.
  • Google API Integration: Full OAuth 2.0 flow with Gmail (fetch, send, label) and Google Calendar (availability checking, event creation, free slot detection with working-hours awareness).
  • Persistence & Learning: SQLAlchemy/SQLite database tracking classifications, drafts, approvals, and user feedback to build an audit trail and support future model improvement.
  • Graceful Degradation: Every AI agent includes fallback strategies (heuristic keyword matching, template-based drafts) so the app remains functional even when the LLM is unavailable.

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
A fully functional, production-structured application that demonstrates end-to-end LLM integration — from prompt engineering and chain composition to API orchestration and state management. The security-first design (layered approvals, sensitive content detection, trusted sender lists) reflects real-world considerations for AI-assisted communication. The project solidified practical skills in LangChain, Google Cloud APIs, OAuth 2.0, SQLAlchemy, and Streamlit, with clean separation of concerns across agents, services, database, and UI layers.

Tech stack: Python · LangChain · HuggingFace · Streamlit · SQLAlchemy · Gmail API · Google Calendar API · OAuth 2.0

docs.title: Configuration Reference
docs.text: This page documents all configuration options available in Gmail Agent.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Configure Gmail Agent by setting these variables in your .env file.

docs.title: Required Variables
docs.text: Variable Description Example HUGGINGFACE_API_KEY HuggingFace API token for LLM inference hf_xxxxxxxxxx GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID Google OAuth 2.0 client ID xxxxx.apps.googleusercontent.com GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET Google OAuth 2.0 client secret GOCSPX-xxxxxxxxxx

docs.title: Optional Variables
docs.text: Variable Description Default LLM_MODEL_ID HuggingFace model for AI tasks meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct CONFIDENCE_THRESHOLD Minimum confidence for auto-approval (0.0-1.0) 0.7

docs.title: Example .env File
docs.text:
# HuggingFace API Configuration
HUGGINGFACE_API_KEY=hf_your_api_key_here

# Google OAuth Configuration
GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=123456789-abcdefg.apps.googleusercontent.com
GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=GOCSPX-your_client_secret

# LLM Configuration (optional)
LLM_MODEL_ID=meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct

# Agent Configuration (optional)
CONFIDENCE_THRESHOLD=0.7

docs.title: Google OAuth Scopes
docs.text:
Gmail Agent requests these OAuth scopes:

Scope Purpose gmail.readonly Read email messages and labels gmail.send Send emails via Gmail gmail.modify Modify email labels (mark read/unread) calendar Read and create calendar events

docs.title: Email Classification Categories
docs.text:
Emails are classified into four categories:

Category Constant Description Needs Reply NEEDS_REPLY Requires a response from user FYI Only FYI_ONLY Informational, no action needed Meeting Request MEETING_REQUEST Contains meeting/scheduling request Task/Action TASK_ACTION Requires action but not email reply

docs.title: Approval Flags
docs.text:
Emails may be flagged for manual review:

Flag Constant Trigger Unknown Sender unknown_sender Sender not in trusted list Sensitive Content sensitive_content Contains sensitive keywords Low Confidence low_confidence Classification confidence below threshold

docs.title: Sensitive Keywords
docs.text:
Default keywords that trigger sensitive content flags:

SENSITIVE_KEYWORDS = [
    "urgent",
    "deadline",
    "contract",
    "payment",
    "$",
    "invoice",
    "legal",
    "confidential",
    "asap",
    "immediately",
]

To customize this list, edit config.py.

docs.title: File Paths
docs.text:
Gmail Agent uses these default paths:

Path Purpose data/ Data directory data/token.json Google OAuth token data/credentials.json Google OAuth credentials (optional) data/gmail_agent.db SQLite database

docs.title: Database Schema
docs.text: Gmail Agent uses SQLite with SQLAlchemy. Key tables:

docs.title: Classifications
docs.text:
Stores email classification history:

  • email_id: Gmail message ID
  • category: Classification category
  • confidence: Confidence score
  • flags: Approval flags (JSON)
  • created_at: Timestamp

docs.title: Drafts
docs.text:
Stores generated reply drafts:

  • draft_id: Unique identifier
  • email_id: Original email ID
  • content: Draft text
  • status: pending/approved/rejected
  • created_at: Timestamp

docs.title: Trusted Senders
docs.text:
Stores trusted email addresses:

  • email: Email address
  • name: Display name (optional)
  • added_at: Timestamp

docs.title: Confidence Threshold
docs.text:
The confidence threshold determines when emails need manual review:

Threshold Auto-Approved Flagged for Review 0.5 > 50% confidence ≤ 50% confidence 0.7 > 70% confidence ≤ 70% confidence 0.9 > 90% confidence ≤ 90% confidence

Lower threshold = More automation, less oversight Higher threshold = Less automation, more oversight

docs.title: LLM Models
docs.text: Compatible models for the Inference API:

docs.title: Recommended
docs.text: Model ID Parameters Notes meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct 7B Default, well-balanced meta-llama/Llama-2-7b-chat-hf 7B Requires license acceptance HuggingFaceH4/zephyr-7b-beta 7B Good for helpful responses

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Models must:

  • Be available on HuggingFace Inference API
  • Support text generation
  • Accept instruction-style prompts

docs.title: Logging
docs.text:
Gmail Agent logs to stdout with this format:

%(asctime)s - %(name)s - %(levelname)s - %(message)s

Default level is INFO. To change, modify app.py:

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

docs.title: Request Timeouts
docs.text:
HuggingFace API requests have default timeouts. For slow models:

# In services/llm_service.py
timeout = 60  # seconds

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text:
Free HuggingFace tier has rate limits. Consider:

  • Batching classification requests
  • Using Inference Endpoints for production
  • Adding delays between requests

docs.title: Calendar
docs.text: The Calendar view integrates with Google Calendar to help you manage schedules and respond to meeting requests extracted from emails.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Gmail Agent connects to your Google Calendar to:

  • Display upcoming events
  • Process meeting requests from emails
  • Find available time slots
  • Schedule new events

docs.title: Event List
docs.text:
The calendar view shows your upcoming events:

Field Description Title Event name Date/Time When the event occurs Duration Length of the event Location Physical or virtual meeting location Attendees Other participants

docs.title: Time Range
docs.text: By default, the view shows events for the next 7 days. You can adjust this in Settings.

docs.title: Meeting Requests
docs.text:
When Gmail Agent classifies an email as MEETING_REQUEST, it extracts:

  • Proposed meeting times
  • Meeting subject/purpose
  • Required attendees
  • Suggested location or video call link

docs.title: Processing Meeting Requests
docs.text:
1. View the extracted meeting details
  2. Check your calendar for conflicts
  3. Accept, decline, or propose an alternative

docs.title: Finding Available Slots
docs.text:
Click Find Availability to:

  1. Scan your calendar for free time
  2. Display available slots matching the proposed duration
  3. Select a slot to accept or counter-propose

docs.title: Creating Events
docs.text: For confirmed meetings, Gmail Agent can create calendar events:

docs.title: Event Details
docs.text: Field Required Description Title Yes Meeting name Start Time Yes When it begins End Time Yes When it ends Description No Meeting notes or agenda Location No Physical address or video link Attendees No Email addresses to invite

docs.title: Sending Invitations
docs.text:
When you add attendees, Gmail Agent can:

  • Send calendar invitations
  • Track responses
  • Update event status

docs.title: Calendar Permissions
docs.text:
Gmail Agent requests the calendar scope which allows:

  • Reading your calendar events
  • Creating new events
  • Modifying events it created
  • Sending calendar invitations

Privacy

Gmail Agent only reads event times and titles for availability checking. It does not analyze event content.

docs.title: Automatic Detection
docs.text:
Emails classified as MEETING_REQUEST are linked to the Calendar view:

  • Click "Schedule" from the Inbox
  • View extracted details in Calendar
  • Create the event directly

docs.title: Reply Integration
docs.text:
When scheduling a meeting:

  1. Create the calendar event
  2. Gmail Agent drafts a confirmation email
  3. Review and send the confirmation

docs.title: Handling Conflicts
docs.text:
If a proposed meeting conflicts with existing events:

  1. Gmail Agent highlights the conflict
  2. Shows alternative available times
  3. Helps draft a counter-proposal email

docs.title: Keeping Calendars Clean
docs.text:
• Regularly review and remove outdated events
  • Use consistent naming for easy searching
  • Block focus time to prevent over-scheduling

docs.title: Meeting Request Best Practices
docs.text:
• Always verify extracted details before accepting
  • Check time zones for remote meetings
  • Include video call links in event descriptions

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
If calendar events aren't appearing:

  • Verify Google Calendar API is enabled
  • Check OAuth permissions include calendar scope
  • Refresh the calendar view
  • Re-authenticate if necessary

docs.title: Drafts
docs.text: The Drafts view is where you review, edit, and approve AI-generated email replies before sending.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
When you click "Draft Reply" on an email in the Inbox, Gmail Agent:

  1. Analyzes the original email context
  2. Generates an appropriate response
  3. Saves the draft for your review

All pending drafts appear in this view.

docs.title: Draft List
docs.text:
Each draft card displays:

Field Description To Recipient email address Subject Reply subject (typically "Re: Original Subject") Original Email Preview of the email being replied to Draft Content The AI-generated response Created When the draft was generated

docs.title: Reading the Draft
docs.text:
Click on a draft to expand its full content. Review:

  • Tone: Is it appropriate for the recipient?
  • Content: Does it address all points in the original email?
  • Accuracy: Are facts and details correct?
  • Length: Is it appropriately concise or detailed?

docs.title: Editing Content
docs.text:
Click Edit to modify the draft:

  1. Make your changes in the text editor
  2. Adjust tone, add details, or fix errors
  3. Click Save to update the draft

Keep AI Context

Minor edits work best. For major rewrites, consider regenerating the draft.

docs.title: Regenerating
docs.text:
If the draft doesn't meet your needs, click Regenerate to:

  1. Create a new AI-generated response
  2. Use updated context if available
  3. Replace the current draft

You can regenerate as many times as needed.

docs.title: Approve and Send
docs.text:
Click Approve & Send to:

  1. Finalize the draft
  2. Send via Gmail API
  3. Move the email to sent folder
  4. Remove from drafts list

No Undo

Once sent, the email cannot be recalled. Review carefully before approving.

docs.title: Reject
docs.text:
Click Reject to:

  1. Discard the draft
  2. Remove from drafts list
  3. Keep the original email in inbox

Use reject when:

  • You decide not to reply
  • You want to write manually instead
  • The draft is not salvageable

docs.title: Draft Status
docs.text:
Drafts can have different statuses:

Status Description Pending Awaiting your review Edited You've made modifications Flagged Contains sensitive content or unknown recipient

docs.title: Sensitive Draft Handling
docs.text: Drafts flagged for extra review show warning indicators:

docs.title: Sensitive Keywords
docs.text:
If the original email or draft contains sensitive keywords, a warning appears. Review:

  • Financial implications
  • Legal language
  • Commitment or promises

docs.title: Unknown Recipient
docs.text:
If replying to someone not in your trusted list, verify:

  • Email address is correct
  • You intend to send to this person
  • Content is appropriate for a new contact

docs.title: Review Checklist
docs.text:
Before approving a draft:

  • [ ] Greeting matches relationship (formal/informal)
  • [ ] All questions from original email are addressed
  • [ ] No factual errors or hallucinations
  • [ ] Tone is appropriate
  • [ ] No sensitive information accidentally shared
  • [ ] Spelling and grammar are correct

docs.title: Common Edits
docs.text:
Typical changes you might make:

  • Personalization: Add specific details or context
  • Softening: Make requests less demanding
  • Clarification: Expand on brief AI responses
  • Sign-off: Use your preferred closing

docs.title: When to Regenerate
docs.text:
Consider regenerating when:

  • Wrong tone (too formal/informal)
  • Misunderstood the original email
  • Missing key points
  • Factually incorrect

docs.title: Inbox
docs.text: The Inbox is your primary workspace for viewing and processing emails. Gmail Agent connects to your Gmail account and displays recent emails with AI-powered classification.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The Inbox view shows:

  • List of recent emails from your Gmail inbox
  • Sender, subject, and preview for each email
  • Classification badges for processed emails
  • Action buttons for classification and drafting

docs.title: Email List
docs.text:
Emails are displayed in reverse chronological order (newest first). Each email card shows:

Field Description From Sender name and email address Subject Email subject line Preview First few lines of email content Date When the email was received Classification Category badge (if classified)

docs.title: Classification
docs.text:
Click Classify on any email to analyze it with AI. The classifier:

  1. Reads the email content and metadata
  2. Determines the appropriate category
  3. Calculates a confidence score
  4. Flags emails requiring manual review

docs.title: Categories
docs.text: Category Badge Color Description NEEDS_REPLY Blue Email requires a response from you FYI_ONLY Gray Informational only, no action needed MEETING_REQUEST Purple Contains meeting invitation or scheduling request TASK_ACTION Orange Requires action but not an email reply

docs.title: Confidence Score
docs.text:
Each classification includes a confidence score (0.0 to 1.0):

  • High confidence (0.7+): Classification is likely accurate
  • Medium confidence (0.5-0.7): Review recommended
  • Low confidence (<0.5): Manual review required

The confidence threshold can be adjusted in Settings.

docs.title: Approval Flags
docs.text: Emails may be flagged for additional review. Flags appear as warning badges:

docs.title: Unknown Sender
docs.text:
The sender is not in your trusted senders list. This helps catch:

  • Potential phishing attempts
  • Unsolicited emails
  • First-time correspondents

Action: Review the email carefully. Add the sender to trusted list if legitimate.

docs.title: Sensitive Content
docs.text:
The email contains sensitive keywords such as:

  • Financial terms: "payment", "invoice", "$"
  • Urgency: "urgent", "asap", "immediately"
  • Legal: "contract", "legal", "confidential"

Action: Review the classification and draft carefully before taking action.

docs.title: Low Confidence
docs.text:
The AI classification confidence is below your configured threshold.

Action: Review the email content and manually verify the classification.

docs.title: Generating Drafts
docs.text:
For emails classified as NEEDS_REPLY, click Draft Reply to:

  1. Generate an AI-written response
  2. Maintain appropriate tone and context
  3. Create a draft for your review

The draft appears in the Drafts section for editing and approval.

docs.title: Efficient Processing
docs.text:
1. Start with high-confidence, trusted sender emails
  2. Process flagged emails with extra attention
  3. Batch similar emails together

docs.title: Managing Volume
docs.text:
• Focus on NEEDS_REPLY emails first
  • Archive FYI_ONLY emails after reviewing
  • Handle MEETING_REQUEST emails in the Calendar view
  • Track TASK_ACTION items separately

docs.title: Building Trust
docs.text:
Add legitimate senders to your trusted list to:

  • Reduce approval friction
  • Speed up classification
  • Build a personalized sender database

docs.title: Refreshing Emails
docs.text:
Click Refresh to fetch the latest emails from Gmail. The inbox automatically syncs when you:

  • Open the application
  • Navigate to the Inbox view
  • Complete a classification action

docs.title: Settings
docs.text: The Settings view allows you to configure Gmail Agent's behavior, manage API credentials, and customize AI parameters.

docs.title: Connection Status
docs.text:
Shows your current connection status:

  • Connected: Google account is linked
  • Not Connected: Authentication required

docs.title: Connect / Disconnect
docs.text:
Connect Google Account: Initiates OAuth flow to authorize Gmail and Calendar access.

Disconnect: Removes saved credentials. You'll need to re-authenticate to use Gmail Agent.

Revoking Access

Disconnecting removes local tokens. To fully revoke access, visit Google Account Permissions.

docs.title: HuggingFace API Key
docs.text:
Your HuggingFace API token for LLM inference:

hf_xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

Click Update to save a new token. The token is stored in your .env file.

docs.title: LLM Model
docs.text:
Select which HuggingFace model to use for classification and drafting:

Model Description meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct Default. Balanced speed and quality meta-llama/Llama-2-7b-chat-hf Alternative instruction-tuned model HuggingFaceH4/zephyr-7b-beta Optimized for helpful responses

Enter a custom model ID to use any HuggingFace Inference API compatible model.

docs.title: Confidence Threshold
docs.text:
Minimum confidence score (0.0 - 1.0) for automatic acceptance:

Threshold Behavior 0.5 Accept more classifications, more manual reviews 0.7 Default. Balanced automation and oversight 0.9 Stricter. Most emails flagged for review

Lower values = more automation, higher risk of errors. Higher values = more manual review, better accuracy.

docs.title: Sensitive Keywords
docs.text:
List of keywords that trigger sensitive content flags:

Default keywords:

  • urgent, deadline
  • contract, payment, invoice
  • legal, confidential
  • asap, immediately
  • $ (currency symbol)

Add custom keywords by editing the config.py file.

docs.title: Managing Trusted List
docs.text:
Email addresses in your trusted list don't trigger the "unknown sender" flag.

Add Sender: Enter an email address to add to the trusted list.

Remove: Click the X next to an address to remove it.

Import: Bulk import from a text file (one address per line).

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
Trusted senders:

  • Skip unknown sender warnings
  • Process faster in workflows
  • Reduce approval friction

docs.title: Recommendations
docs.text:
Add to trusted list:

  • Colleagues and team members
  • Frequent contacts
  • Known automated senders (calendars, receipts)

Do NOT add:

  • Unknown addresses
  • Marketing/newsletter senders
  • Anyone you want extra review for

docs.title: Database Location
docs.text:
Gmail Agent stores data in:

data/gmail_agent.db

This SQLite database contains:

  • Classification history
  • Draft records
  • Trusted sender list
  • Application state

docs.title: Clearing Data
docs.text:
Clear Classification History: Removes past classifications while keeping settings.

Clear All Data: Resets the database to initial state.

Data Loss

Clearing data cannot be undone. Export important information first.

docs.title: Token Storage
docs.text:
OAuth tokens are stored in:

data/token.json

This file contains your Google authentication credentials. Keep it secure and never share it.

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Settings can also be configured via environment variables in .env:

Variable Setting HUGGINGFACE_API_KEY HuggingFace API Key GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID Google OAuth Client ID GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET Google OAuth Client Secret LLM_MODEL_ID LLM Model CONFIDENCE_THRESHOLD Confidence Threshold

Environment variables take precedence over UI settings on application restart.

docs.title: Saving Settings
docs.text:
Most settings save automatically when changed. For environment variable changes:

  1. Edit the .env file
  2. Restart the application
# Stop with Ctrl+C, then restart
uv run streamlit run app.py

docs.title: First Run
docs.text: With your environment configured, you're ready to launch Gmail Agent and connect your Google account.

docs.title: Starting the Application
docs.text:
Launch Gmail Agent with:

uv run streamlit run app.py

The application opens in your default browser at http://localhost:8501.

docs.title: Connecting Your Google Account
docs.text: On first launch, you'll see a warning that you're not connected. Follow these steps to authenticate:

docs.title: Step 1: Navigate to Settings
docs.text: Click Settings in the sidebar navigation.

docs.title: Step 2: Connect Google Account
docs.text: Click the Connect Google Account button. This opens a new browser window for Google OAuth.

docs.title: Step 3: Complete OAuth Flow
docs.text:
1. Select your Google account
  2. Review the requested permissions
  3. Click Allow

Unverified App Warning

Since your app is in testing mode, Google will show a warning. Click Advanced then Go to Gmail Agent (unsafe) to proceed. This is normal for development.

docs.title: Step 4: Authorization Complete
docs.text:
After successful authorization:

  • The browser window will close automatically
  • Gmail Agent shows "Connected" in the sidebar
  • Your OAuth token is saved locally in data/token.json

docs.title: Exploring the Interface
docs.text: Once connected, you can explore the four main sections:

docs.title: Inbox
docs.text:
View and process your emails:

  • See recent emails from your inbox
  • Classify emails with AI
  • Generate reply drafts

docs.title: Drafts
docs.text:
Review AI-generated replies:

  • Edit draft content
  • Approve and send
  • Reject and regenerate

docs.title: Calendar
docs.text:
Manage your schedule:

  • View upcoming events
  • Process meeting requests from emails
  • Find available time slots

docs.title: Settings
docs.text:
Configure the application:

  • API credentials
  • LLM model selection
  • Confidence thresholds
  • Trusted sender management

docs.title: Basic Workflow
docs.text:
Here's a typical workflow for processing emails:

  1. Go to Inbox - View your recent emails
  2. Classify an Email - Click "Classify" to analyze the email content
  3. Review Classification - See the category and confidence score
  4. Generate Reply - Click "Draft Reply" for emails that need responses
  5. Review Draft - Go to Drafts to edit and approve the reply
  6. Send - Approve the draft to send via Gmail

docs.title: Understanding Classifications
docs.text:
Gmail Agent categorizes emails into four types:

Category Description Typical Action NEEDS_REPLY Email requires a response Generate a draft reply FYI_ONLY Informational, no action needed Archive or mark as read MEETING_REQUEST Contains a meeting invitation Check calendar availability TASK_ACTION Requires action but not a reply Add to your task list

docs.title: Approval Flags
docs.text:
Certain emails are flagged for manual review:

Flag Reason Unknown Sender Sender is not in your trusted list Sensitive Content Email contains keywords like "urgent", "contract", "payment" Low Confidence AI classification confidence is below threshold

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Learn about Inbox features in detail
  • Configure Settings for your preferences
  • Review the Configuration Reference for all options

docs.title: Google Cloud Setup
docs.text: Gmail Agent requires access to the Gmail and Google Calendar APIs. This guide walks you through setting up OAuth credentials in Google Cloud Console.

docs.title: Step 1: Create a Google Cloud Project
docs.text:
1. Go to Google Cloud Console
  2. Click the project dropdown at the top of the page
  3. Click New Project
  4. Enter a project name (e.g., "Gmail Agent")
  5. Click Create

docs.title: Step 2: Enable Required APIs
docs.text: Enable both the Gmail API and Google Calendar API:

docs.title: Enable Gmail API
docs.text:
1. In the Cloud Console, go to APIs & Services > Library
  2. Search for "Gmail API"
  3. Click on Gmail API
  4. Click Enable

docs.title: Enable Google Calendar API
docs.text:
1. Return to APIs & Services > Library
  2. Search for "Google Calendar API"
  3. Click on Google Calendar API
  4. Click Enable

docs.title: Step 3: Configure OAuth Consent Screen
docs.text:
Before creating credentials, you need to configure the OAuth consent screen:

  1. Go to APIs & Services > OAuth consent screen
  2. Select External as the user type (unless you have a Google Workspace account)
  3. Click Create

Fill in the required information:

Field Value App name Gmail Agent User support email Your email address Developer contact email Your email address
  1. Click Save and Continue

docs.title: Add Scopes
docs.text:
1. Click Add or Remove Scopes
  2. Search for and select these scopes:
    • https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.readonly
    • https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.send
    • https://www.googleapis.com/auth/gmail.modify
    • https://www.googleapis.com/auth/calendar
  3. Click Update
  4. Click Save and Continue

docs.title: Add Test Users
docs.text:
Since the app is in testing mode:

  1. Click Add Users
  2. Enter your Google email address
  3. Click Add
  4. Click Save and Continue

Test Users

While your app is in "Testing" status, only the email addresses you add as test users can authorize the app.

docs.title: Step 4: Create OAuth Credentials
docs.text:
1. Go to APIs & Services > Credentials
  2. Click Create Credentials > OAuth client ID
  3. Select Desktop app as the application type
  4. Enter a name (e.g., "Gmail Agent Desktop")
  5. Click Create

You will see a dialog with your credentials:

  • Client ID - Copy this value
  • Client Secret - Copy this value

docs.title: Step 5: Configure Gmail Agent
docs.text:
Add the credentials to your .env file:

GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=your_client_id.apps.googleusercontent.com
GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=your_client_secret

Download Credentials

You can also download the credentials as a JSON file by clicking the download button. This can be useful as a backup.

docs.title: Required Permissions
docs.text:
Gmail Agent requests the following permissions:

Scope Purpose gmail.readonly Read email messages and labels gmail.send Send emails and reply drafts gmail.modify Modify email labels (read/unread) calendar Read and create calendar events

docs.title: "Access blocked: This app's request is invalid"
docs.text:
This usually means the OAuth consent screen is not configured correctly. Verify:

  • All required fields are filled in
  • You added yourself as a test user
  • The app is published or in testing mode

docs.title: "Error 400: redirect_uri_mismatch"
docs.text: Make sure you selected Desktop app when creating OAuth credentials, not Web application.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Continue to HuggingFace Setup to configure your LLM API access.

docs.title: HuggingFace Setup
docs.text: Gmail Agent uses HuggingFace's Inference API to power its AI features. This guide walks you through creating and configuring your API token.

docs.title: Step 1: Create a HuggingFace Account
docs.text:
If you don't already have a HuggingFace account:

  1. Go to HuggingFace
  2. Click Sign Up in the top right
  3. Complete the registration process
  4. Verify your email address

docs.title: Step 2: Generate an API Token
docs.text:
1. Log in to HuggingFace
  2. Go to Settings > Access Tokens
  3. Click New token

Configure the token:

Field Value Name Gmail Agent (or any descriptive name) Type Read
  1. Click Generate token
  2. Copy the token (starts with hf_)

Save Your Token

You can only see the full token once. Copy it immediately and store it securely.

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Gmail Agent
docs.text:
Add the token to your .env file:

HUGGINGFACE_API_KEY=hf_your_api_key_here

docs.title: Choosing a Model
docs.text:
Gmail Agent uses the HuggingFace Inference API to access LLMs. By default, it uses Mistral-7B-Instruct:

LLM_MODEL_ID=meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct

docs.title: Recommended Models
docs.text:
Model Description meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct Default. Good balance of speed and quality meta-llama/Llama-2-7b-chat-hf Meta's Llama 2 chat model HuggingFaceH4/zephyr-7b-beta Fine-tuned for helpful responses

Model Availability

Some models may require accepting terms of use on the model page before you can use them via the API.

docs.title: API Rate Limits
docs.text:
The free HuggingFace Inference API has rate limits:

  • Requests are queued during high traffic
  • Large inputs may be truncated
  • Some models have longer inference times

For production use, consider HuggingFace Inference Endpoints for dedicated resources.

docs.title: Verifying Your Setup
docs.text:
Test your API key with this quick check:

curl -X POST \
  -H "Authorization: Bearer hf_your_api_key" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"inputs": "Hello, how are you?"}' \
  https://api-inference.huggingface.co/models/meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct

A successful response will return generated text.

docs.title: "Model is currently loading"
docs.text: The first request to a model may take longer as HuggingFace loads it into memory. Wait a moment and try again.

docs.title: "Rate limit exceeded"
docs.text: You've made too many requests. Wait a few minutes before trying again, or upgrade to a paid plan.

docs.title: "Authorization header is invalid"
docs.text:
Verify your token:

  • Starts with hf_
  • Has no extra spaces
  • Is correctly copied to .env

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Your setup is almost complete. Continue to First Run to launch Gmail Agent and connect your Google account.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This guide walks you through installing Gmail Agent and its dependencies.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have the following installed:

  • Python 3.11 or higher - Download Python
  • uv package manager - Install uv
  • Git - Download Git

You will also need:

  • A Google Cloud account (for Gmail and Calendar APIs)
  • A HuggingFace account (for LLM API access)

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/PierreExeter/gmail-agent.git
cd gmail-agent

docs.title: 2. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
Gmail Agent uses uv for dependency management. Install all dependencies with:

uv sync

This creates a virtual environment and installs all required packages.

docs.title: 3. Set Up Environment Variables
docs.text:
Copy the example environment file:

cp .env.example .env

Open .env in your editor and configure the required variables:

# Required
HUGGINGFACE_API_KEY=hf_your_api_key
GOOGLE_CLIENT_ID=your_client_id.apps.googleusercontent.com
GOOGLE_CLIENT_SECRET=your_client_secret

# Optional (with defaults shown)
LLM_MODEL_ID=meta-llama/Llama-3.1-8B-Instruct
CONFIDENCE_THRESHOLD=0.7

Keep Your Secrets Safe

Never commit your .env file to version control. It contains sensitive credentials.

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
Run a quick check to ensure everything is set up correctly:

uv run python -c "import streamlit; import langchain; print('Installation successful!')"

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
Before you can use Gmail Agent, you need to:

  1. Set up Google Cloud credentials
  2. Configure your HuggingFace API token
  3. Complete your first run

docs.title: Troubleshooting & FAQ
docs.text: Common issues and solutions for Gmail Agent.

docs.title: "Access blocked: This app's request is invalid"
docs.text:
Cause: OAuth consent screen not configured correctly.

Solution:

  1. Go to Google Cloud Console > APIs & Services > OAuth consent screen
  2. Verify all required fields are filled
  3. Add your email as a test user
  4. Ensure app is in "Testing" mode

docs.title: "Error 400: redirect_uri_mismatch"
docs.text:
Cause: Wrong OAuth credential type.

Solution:

  1. Go to Google Cloud Console > APIs & Services > Credentials
  2. Delete the existing OAuth 2.0 Client ID
  3. Create a new one with type Desktop app (not Web application)
  4. Update .env with new credentials

docs.title: "Token has been expired or revoked"
docs.text:
Cause: OAuth token is no longer valid.

Solution:

  1. Delete data/token.json
  2. Restart Gmail Agent
  3. Re-authenticate via Settings > Connect Google Account

docs.title: "The caller does not have permission"
docs.text:
Cause: Required API not enabled or scope missing.

Solution:

  1. Verify Gmail API is enabled in Google Cloud Console
  2. Verify Google Calendar API is enabled
  3. Delete data/token.json and re-authenticate

docs.title: "Model is currently loading"
docs.text:
Cause: HuggingFace is loading the model into memory.

Solution: Wait 30-60 seconds and try again. First requests after idle periods are slower.

docs.title: "Rate limit exceeded"
docs.text:
Cause: Too many HuggingFace API requests.

Solution:

  • Wait a few minutes before retrying
  • Consider upgrading to HuggingFace Pro
  • Use a dedicated Inference Endpoint for production

docs.title: "Authorization header is invalid"
docs.text:
Cause: Invalid HuggingFace API token.

Solution:

  1. Generate a new token at HuggingFace Settings
  2. Ensure token starts with hf_
  3. Update .env with the new token
  4. Restart the application

docs.title: "Model not found"
docs.text:
Cause: Invalid model ID or model requires authorization.

Solution:

  1. Verify the model exists on HuggingFace Hub
  2. Accept any license/terms on the model page
  3. Check if model is available for Inference API
  4. Use a different model

docs.title: Emails not loading
docs.text:
Cause: Gmail API connection issue.

Solution:

  1. Check connection status in Settings
  2. If disconnected, re-authenticate
  3. Verify Gmail API is enabled in Google Cloud Console
  4. Check browser console for error messages

docs.title: Classification taking too long
docs.text:
Cause: LLM inference delay.

Solution:

  • Wait for response (can take 30+ seconds)
  • Try a smaller/faster model
  • Check HuggingFace status for outages

docs.title: Wrong classifications
docs.text:
Cause: LLM interpretation varies.

Solution:

  • Review and manually correct
  • Adjust confidence threshold higher
  • Try a different LLM model
  • Report persistent issues

docs.title: Calendar events not showing
docs.text:
Cause: Calendar API not authorized.

Solution:

  1. Verify Google Calendar API is enabled
  2. Delete data/token.json
  3. Re-authenticate to get calendar scope
  4. Refresh the Calendar view

docs.title: Can't create events
docs.text:
Cause: Permission or API issue.

Solution:

  1. Verify calendar write permission in OAuth scopes
  2. Check that calendar is not read-only
  3. Re-authenticate if needed

docs.title: Streamlit won't start
docs.text:
Cause: Missing dependencies or Python version.

Solution:

# Ensure Python 3.11+
python --version

# Reinstall dependencies
uv sync

# Try running directly
uv run streamlit run app.py --server.port 8501

docs.title: Port 8501 already in use
docs.text:
Cause: Another instance running.

Solution:

# Find and kill existing process
lsof -i :8501
kill -9 <PID>

# Or use different port
uv run streamlit run app.py --server.port 8502

docs.title: Database errors
docs.text:
Cause: Corrupted database file.

Solution:

# Backup and remove database
mv data/gmail_agent.db data/gmail_agent.db.backup

# Restart app to create fresh database
uv run streamlit run app.py

docs.title: "Module not found" errors
docs.text:
Cause: Dependencies not installed.

Solution:

# Sync dependencies
uv sync

# If still failing, recreate environment
rm -rf .venv
uv sync

docs.title: Environment variables not loading
docs.text:
Cause: .env file issues.

Solution:

  1. Verify .env exists in project root
  2. Check for syntax errors (no quotes around values usually)
  3. Restart the application after changes

docs.title: Settings not saving
docs.text:
Cause: File permission or path issue.

Solution:

  1. Check write permissions on data/ directory
  2. Verify .env file is writable
  3. Check for disk space issues

docs.title: Reporting Issues
docs.text:
When reporting issues, include:

  1. Python version (python --version)
  2. Operating system
  3. Error messages (full traceback)
  4. Steps to reproduce

docs.title: Debug Mode
docs.text:
Enable debug logging:

# In app.py, change:
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

docs.title: Checking Logs
docs.text:
View application logs in the terminal where Streamlit is running.

For more verbose output:

uv run streamlit run app.py --logger.level debug

docs.title: Is my email data stored?
docs.text:
Gmail Agent stores:

  • Classification history (email IDs and categories)
  • Draft content you generate
  • Trusted sender list

Email content is processed in memory and not persisted.

docs.title: Can Gmail Agent send emails without approval?
docs.text: No. All email actions require explicit user approval. There is no automatic sending.

docs.title: Does Gmail Agent work offline?
docs.text:
No. Gmail Agent requires internet access for:

  • Gmail API
  • Google Calendar API
  • HuggingFace Inference API

docs.title: Can I use a local LLM?
docs.text: Not currently. Gmail Agent is designed for HuggingFace Inference API. Local model support may be added in future versions.

docs.title: How do I revoke Google access?
docs.text:
1. Disconnect in Gmail Agent Settings
  2. Visit Google Account Permissions
  3. Find "Gmail Agent" and click Remove Access

docs.title: Is Gmail Agent secure?
docs.text:
Gmail Agent follows security best practices:

  • OAuth 2.0 for authentication
  • Tokens stored locally only
  • No data sent to third parties (except APIs)
  • Human approval required for all actions

Always keep your .env file and data/ directory secure.
